Hiya!

So I'm currently in Career mode at say tech level 3 or 4. Now I have tried getting into Spaceplanes, with proper success. Except...

 

The landing gear. I'm limited to the two basic gear types, the steerable and the static ones with brakes. The static ones appear to be buggy as %&£àè so I use three steerable ones (in taildragger formation, don't judge) with friction overridden to 0. (that setting appears to both help against sudden implosions of the gear and "veering-of-the-runway" syndrome )

Then we have spring strength and damper strength. I keep these at 1 because other settings don't appear to improve anything, and also I can't bend my head around how they are supposed to work (no matter how much I google about them, i find nothing that explains them in a way that matches my experience with them or makes me understand them in any way.)

crafts heavier than ~18 tons break the landing gear on liftoff. For no apparent reason, the stress jumps from 3~6 to sudden explosion the instant the wheels stop touching the ground. (craft still lifts of though) landing appears impossible, so I went full Kerbal and slapped 10 chutes on it and called it a day. (works every time)

now my latest craft is a taildragger with only 9 tons dry weight. And I do manage to land it (success rate ~80%, consolation fireworks rate ~20%) without breaking the gears if I land with -2 vertical speed tops. Is this common?

And the flaps.

I tried to put on ailerons close to the CoM and rigged them to work like flaps (they extend when I push [G] idle otherwise) . However, whenever I use them they appear only to produce some minor drag, I can't determine if I get any additional lift at all and I believe it makes landing only harder. Or are flaps something that is yet to be unlocked and I just have to deal with my situation somehow?

While I'm at it: spoliers.

please tell me I can make spoilers somehow... :c

 

so guys and gals...

am I currently limited by my tech, or is there something I haven't looked into enough? (like spoilers, landing gear settings etc.)

I believe my most pressing task is to unlock better landing gear ... followed by new engines (using a dozen junos appears nuts)

What did I miss?

Thanks for any help and hints.

Hello, and welcome to the forums! 

Moving question about gameplay to Gameplay Questions.  ("Tech support" is generally for trouble with installs, crash problems, those sorts of technical issues rather than "how do I play the game").

6 hours ago, Zarylo said:

The landing gear

are bugged and broken since an update about 6 months ago, and should be fixed in the next update, 1.2. This is expected soonTM, i.e. we don't have a date. For what it's worth, you're doing almost everything right - taildraggers, for example, are a totally sensible early-career wheel-plan. There are guides on the forum for setting up the wheels and the various sliders, but for the time being there's not really any point in learning the intricacies because the next patch will probably just sweep all that expertise aside. The good news is the first available wheels are really the absolute worst, so if you can get a little further up the tech tree, the next sets of wheels are generally a bit more robust and you won't have the same problems as often (tho don't let me mislead you here, ALL wheels are bugged to some extent at the moment).
 

6 hours ago, Zarylo said:

And the flaps.

I tried to put on ailerons close to the CoM and rigged them to work like flaps (they extend when I push [G] idle otherwise) . However, whenever I use them they appear only to produce some minor drag, I can't determine if I get any additional lift at all and I believe it makes landing only harder. Or are flaps something that is yet to be unlocked and I just have to deal with my situation somehow?

Ok, let's just make sure we're using all the terms correctly/to mean the same thing:

Ailerons are used to roll the plane. They should be put as wide on the lateral 'pitch' axis (width) as possible, and it reduces sheering forces to also put them in line with the centre of mass (CoM) on the longitudinal 'roll' axis (length).
Flaps are used to slow down the stall speed of the plane, so you can land or take off at slower speeds. Their position on the longitudinal axis should be right in line with the CoM or they'll cause pitching instead of just promoting lift - this is much more important than their lateral axis position. In stock KSP, for most planes flaps are generally not really necessary (when the wheels aren't bugged), although you are using them for the right job as you've described.

Flaps certainly do make a difference to stall/take off speeds, but they won't stop you dropping like a brick if/when you cross that line. The gains are also going to be much smaller for very light aircraft because they are generally already very lift-y compared with heavier planes -  it's difficult to make a feather any lighter.

And no flaps are not something to be unlocked (tho AIRBRAKES are), you just put the control surfaces you have in the right places (some of which are confusingly labelled as 'ailerons', so not your bad) and control them at the right times.

6 hours ago, Zarylo said:

While I'm at it: spoliers.

You can make spoilers just like flaps, but you really don't need to and they wouldn't help solve your problems. Spoilers do the exact opposite of flaps - they make the plane have LESS lift. You don't want this if slower landings are your goal.

General tips:
 

  • Use the rotate tool to give your wings a very little angle of attack (so they slope backwards). This will make your plane a little slower, but it will take off and land slower too.
  • Use more wheels - even doubling up can have dramatic effects
  • Use rockets to get Science to unlock better wheels, but when you have them keep the airplane as light as possible
  • some use parts like Cubic Octagonal Struts as skids instead of using wheels since they're pretty tough and less inclined to spontaneously kill you, but these also have drawbacks and can also cause undesirable explosions and death.

Flaps do create lift in KSP but they aren't really necessary in most cases, they are supposed to create some drag that is normal. Spoilers are possible, you just position the control surface around mid wing or a bit closer to the rear and have it deploy up.  From a technical standpoint, it does kill your lift.  However, they too are not really necessary, even less so than Flaps.  In most cases you have plenty of room to glide without needing lift dumpers.

Thing about stock aero is you can just permanently raise the wing AoA instead of using flaps for low speed lift, because the penalties for doing so aren't really what they ought to be - however flaps are somewhat functional. Under FAR flaps are extremely functional even though they don't really work as well as they should.

Ailerons are used to roll the plane. They should be put as wide on the lateral 'pitch' axis (width) as possible, and it reduces sheering forces to also put them in line with the centre of mass (CoM) on the longitudinal 'roll' axis (length).

Great post!  Maybe we should be promoting using "control surfaces" as the general part category, as well as defining all the sub-categories like aileron, elevon, elevator etc.

A minor nitpick - ailerons are most effective when mounted as wide as possible, but that's only good if you want maximum effectiveness.  I often find my planes need the roll and yaw authority reduced, and pitch authority increased (for design reasons that are off-topic).  In some low part count cases, a elevon control surface works best with a narrow placement to get the right combination of pitch and roll authority from a single control surface.

Thank you all for taking the time to help me out!

The reason why I asked about spoilers is mainly because I have no brakes. Not pre-landing nor post-landing. I would'n never brake during the landing itself, don't worry. =)

I learned flying at the ripe age of 7 with my dad's WWII combat flight simulator (which is also probably why I do taildraggers. Focke Wulf anyone? Maybe a Lockheed P-38?)

The reason I ask for flaps is because I want to reduce my horizontal landing speed. The runway is only that long you know, and I still have no way to brake other than do a 180 and thrust retrograde. Which is risky because the wheels might explode if I do that while going faster than 24m/s. I guess I have to put a chute on the plane instead. But it's single use and a lot of extra weight. Two reasons to look for alternatives.

My lowest horizontal touchdown speed with my aircraft was 30 m/s but that involved hitting a very slim timing window and I'm certain I can't do such maneuvers in practical situations.

However, the flaps I made (out of the aileron-1 part that is first available) doesn't work as well as I hoped it would. It's the main reason for posting this. I wanted to know if it is even possible to create flaps, as I don't know how well the Game engine calculates the physics. Right now it looks like I should remove the flaps entirely to reduce weight. It appears they don't work well enough to justify their weight.

I'll keep experimenting in the future.

Your approach might be part of the issue here.  Your landing speed is definitely doable.  Start further back from the runway and bring your speed down much sooner and come in low.  You should hit your landing speed just after crossing over the runway.  This probably means a powered approach to keep your speed high enough that you do not stall.  

Other than that, I have not had too many issues with the retractable gears.  Depending on how the craft acts on physics load I adjust the spring and dampener settings, and just force it straight down the runway.  Just be herbal on the controls.

9 hours ago, Zarylo said:

The Issue I have is that it is very difficult to align things exactly.

This is true, it's something I guess everybody finds their own ways to solve in the editor. For example usually I build a whole 'wing' subassembly with a gear on it, and then mirror the whole wing by selecting the first/parent radial part from the fuselage. You can also turn snap-to-grid/angle on and off in the editor (which also affects the offset/displace tools), but be warned that the 'grid' is not the same grid for every part on the craft - if you place a part that does not conform to the root grid, any subsequent parts attached to that one will now conform to it's grid instead.

Regarding stopping without brakes:

First, just having brakes could still be the best practical option. Personally I've tended to find the braking wheels work better than the steering wheels, so perhaps it's more a question of how they're used or where they're put rather than either type themselves being worse. Don't forget that the wheels closest to the CoM are bearing a greater share of the craft's weight than wheels further away, so keeping all the wheels near-equidistant from CoM could help with overstress issues.

Slowing down with spoilers is a RL approach, but at the speeds you're talking about (in my 1st- and 2nd-hand experience, 30m/s is on the slow side for most aircraft in KSP and RL too actually) they just won't be very effective - they work better with more airflow, i.e. more speed, so it's another question of diminishing gains - the slower you go, the less you get for them. Even RL jet aircraft don't use their spoilers to stop, just to bleed off some of their rolling speed - they still stop with wheelbrakes.

Since you're already using a taildragger, one approach could be to add a single tail-skid (like many WW1 planes) to give you a lot more tail friction after touchdown and should (as long as it's not too slippery) be a nice stable braking arrangement. The downside is you'll have to steer with the front wheels or rudder only to taxi.

Chutes will also work well.

An extreme option could be to add a small braking rocket (a Sepratron, or a Twitch with an Oscar-B tank) just for stopping once on the ground. Sepratrons would need to be calibrated and fired at a known speed to result in 0 speed or you'd end up still rolling/in reverse. Also, the Wheesley engine has a toggleable reverse-thrust setting, which sweeps all this aside.

And lastly, upgrade the runway at least one level. The basic runway is awful, not flat, breaks everything, and even the grass is just better. If you haven't already upgraded to the 2nd tier, this could literally solve all your problems.

I was reading this question in different places where people said it's not possible without mods. So I gave up on looking for it.

I'll make an example how one can use it:

Let's say you want to create a rocket with 6 boosters in a radial hex pattern around it. on every booster you want to place exactly two surfaces for stabilization. So create a booster first as a root element, then put on the surfaces using mirror mode. finally save the booster and create a new rocket. create the actual rocket and attach a circular array of 6 radial decouplers. now merge the booster you prepared earlier and put it on the decoupler. You will now have a perfectly axis-symmetric rocket with every booster having a pair mirror symmetric stabilizing surfaces (relative to their own subgrid)

It can be done much simpler than that.

Add a single decoupler and booster to your core rocket, with no symmetry. Turn on mirror symmetry and add control surfaces to it. It should default to "symmetry around parent part" rather than "around vessel" since there's only one there, but if not just press "F".

Then switch to hex radial symmetry, pick up the radial decoupler (better than picking up the booster, imo) and place it back exactly where it was.

(edit: also your suggestion of merging probably wouldn't work since the root part of the merged craft needs a free node to be able to connect it to anything. Likewise if you use subassemblies: the part that the subassembly connected with before you hived it off is the part that it'll connect with when you reload it. Building a booster as core part then trying to attach it on the side of a rocket is therefore bound to be a problem)
